no CCaseyPro planFree RSS feed publishing optionsCan I use this for free? Can I publish an RSS feed for free or do I need to be a member?Jan 19I'd be happy to help clarify what you can do for free! However, I need a bit more context - are you asking about:
Claude.ai (this chat interface) - whether you can use it for free and if there are limitations? A specific service or platform for publishing RSS feeds that we were discussing? Something else entirely?
If you're asking about Claude.ai specifically, yes, there is a free tier available that lets you have conversations with me. However, the free tier does have some limitations compared to paid plans (like message limits and access to certain features). For the most current details about what's included in the free tier versus paid plans, I should search Anthropic's documentation to give you accurate information. If you're asking about publishing RSS feeds through a different service or platform, please let me know which one and I can help you find that information!I want to make a rss feed for a podcast, do I need to pay for it?Jan 19No, you don't need to pay to create an RSS feed for a podcast! Here's what you should know: Free options:
You can create an RSS feed completely for free using various podcast hosting platforms that offer free tiers, such as Anchor (now Spotify for Podcasters), Buzzsprout's free plan, or Podbean's free plan You can also manually create your own RSS feed if you have a website - it's just an XML file that follows the podcast RSS specification If you host your audio files on your own server or free cloud storage, you can generate the RSS feed yourself at no cost
What typically costs money:
Hosting your audio files - while some platforms offer limited free hosting, you may eventually need to pay for bandwidth/storage as your podcast grows Advanced features - analytics, multiple shows, removing platform branding, more upload hours per month Distribution help - some paid services make it easier to submit to directories like Apple Podcasts, Spotify, etc. (though you can do this yourself for free)
My recommendation: Start with a free podcast hosting platform like Spotify for Podcasters (formerly Anchor). They'll generate the RSS feed for you automatically, host your audio files, and help you distribute to major podcast directories - all for free. You can always migrate to a paid service later if you need more features. Would you like help understanding how to set up a podcast RSS feed or recommendations for specific free platforms?Can you generate the rss feed code for me?Jan 19Absolutely! I can generate RSS feed code for your podcast. To create a proper RSS feed, I'll need some information from you: Required information:
Podcast title Podcast description Author/host name Podcast category (e.g., Technology, Comedy, Education, etc.) Language (e.g., en-us for English) Your email address (for the feed) Podcast artwork URL (square image, at least 1400x1400px recommended)
For each episode, I'll need:
Episode title Episode description Audio file URL (where your MP3 is hosted) Publication date Episode duration File size (in bytes)
Once you provide this information, I'll create a complete, valid podcast RSS feed in XML format that you can use. You can then:
Upload it to your web server Submit the feed URL to podcast directories like Apple Podcasts, Spotify, etc.

Would you like help with any of these next steps?yesJan 19Great! Let me walk you through the next steps: Step 1: Save the RSS Feed File
Copy all the XML code from the artifact above Open a text editor (Notepad on Windows, TextEdit on Mac, or any code editor) Paste the code Save it as feed.xml or wordle-spoiler.xml (make sure it has the .xml extension)
Step 2: Upload to a Public Location Since your episodes are already on Archive.org, that's a great place to host your RSS feed too! Here are your options: Option A: Archive.org (Recommended since you're already using it)
Go to https://archive.org Sign in or create an account Click "Upload" Upload your feed.xml file to the same collection as your episodes Once uploaded, you'll get a public URL like: https://archive.org/download/your-collection-name/feed.xml
Option B: GitHub Pages (Free and reliable)
Create a free GitHub account Create a new repository Upload your feed.xml file Enable GitHub Pages in settings Your feed will be at: https://yourusername.github.io/repository-name/feed.xml
Option C: Your own website If you have a website, just upload the XML file to your web server. Which option sounds best for you?I just sign into Github, so let's use thatJan 19Perfect! Let's set up your RSS feed on GitHub. Here's what to do: Step 1: Create a New Repository
Go to https://github.com and make sure you're signed in Click the "+" icon in the top right corner Select "New repository" Name it something like wordle-spoiler-podcast or podcast-feed Make sure it's set to Public (required for RSS feeds) Check the box "Add a README file" (this makes the next steps easier) Click "Create repository"
Step 2: Upload Your RSS Feed
In your new repository, click "Add file" ‚Üí "Create new file" Name the file feed.xml Copy the XML code from the artifact above and paste it into the file Scroll down and click "Commit new file"
Step 3: Enable GitHub Pages
In your repository, click "Settings" (top menu) Scroll down the left sidebar and click "Pages" Under "Source", select "Deploy from a branch" Under "Branch", select "main" and "/ (root)" Click "Save" Wait a minute or two, then refresh the page - you'll see a URL like: https://yourusername.github.io/wordle-spoiler-podcast/

When you import an RSS feed into Spotify, you don't manually add episodes through Spotify's interface. The episodes come automatically from your RSS feed. Here's how it works: Your RSS feed is the source of truth - Spotify (and all other podcast platforms) automatically pull episodes from your RSS feed. You don't add episodes through Spotify's dashboard. To add new episodes in the future:
Upload the new episode audio file to Archive.org (or wherever you host it) Edit your feed.xml file on GitHub Add a new
section for the new episode (copying the format of episodes 1 and 2) Commit the changes to GitHub Within a few hours, Spotify (and other platforms) will automatically detect the new episode and add it
Right now, your feed already has 2 episodes, so Spotify should show both "C Where the C Goes" and "How Do You Spell Relief?" automatically. Questions:
Can you see your 2 existing episodes in Spotify's dashboard? Are you trying to add a third episode, or are the first two not showing up?

Let me check your image and see what might be the issue.Failed to fetch: https://archive.org/download/ws_20260119/WS.jpgFailed to fetch https://archive.org/download/ws_20260119/WS.jpgDoneLet me search for Apple Podcasts' image requirements to help you troubleshoot:Searched the webApple Podcasts artwork image requirements specifications10 resultsPodcast Artwork Requirements - Apple Communitydiscussions.apple.comArtwork guide - Apple Podcasts for Creatorspodcasters.apple.comEnsuring Podcast Artwork Meets Apple Podcasts Requirements ‚Äì SoundCloud Help Centerhelp.soundcloud.comSpecs for podcast cover art on Apple Podcasts, Spotify etc | Transistor Helpsupport.transistor.fmPodcast Artwork Specifications | Captivate Help and Supporthelp.captivate.fmPodcast Cover Art Size Preview - Check Cover Art on Podcast Apps | OnlyPodonlypod.comPodcast Artwork Size to be Featured - Apple Communitydiscussions.apple.comHow to Create Podcast Artwork: A Complete Guide - Spreaker Blogblog.spreaker.comApple (Previously iTunes) Podcasts Submission Requirements | Blubrryblubrry.comPodcast Artwork: Logo + Cover Art (with Apple Artwork Guidelines) ‚Äì 48hourslogo Blogwww.48hourslogo.comDoneBased on Apple Podcasts' requirements, here are the most common issues with podcast artwork: Apple Podcasts Image Requirements:
Must be at least 1400x1400 pixels and no larger than 3000x3000 pixels SoundCloud Must be square (same width and height) File size must be below 500KB Apple Community Format: JPG or PNG PNG images must be saved in RGB color space, not CMYK Blubrry Must be hosted on a server that supports HTTP head requests
What's likely wrong with your image: The most common issues are:
File size too large - The image file might be over 500KB Wrong dimensions - Not square or outside the 1400-3000 pixel range Wrong color space - If it's a PNG, it might be in CMYK instead of RGB
How to fix it:
Download your image from Archive.org Check its properties:
Is it square? What are the pixel dimensions? What's the file size?
Use a free tool like:
TinyPNG (https://tinypng.com) to reduce file size Canva or Photoshop to resize to 1400x1400 or 3000x3000 pixels Make sure it's saved as RGB (not CMYK) if using PNG
What specific error message is Apple Podcasts showing you? That will help me pinpoint the exact issue!Art - Artwork must be 3000 x 3000 pixels, JPG or PNG, in RGB color space, and hosted on a server that allows HTTP head requestJan 19Apple is requiring your artwork to be exactly 3000 x 3000 pixels. Download your image from https://archive.org/download/ws_20260119/WS.jpg Use a free tool to resize it to 3000x3000 pixels:
Canva (https://canva.com) - free, easy to use Photoshop or GIMP if you have them Online resizer like https://www.simpleimageresizer.com
Make sure it's:
Exactly 3000 x 3000 pixels JPG or PNG format RGB color space (not CMYK) Under 500KB file size
Re-upload the new 3000x3000 image to Archive.org Update the image URL in your RSS feed if needed
Option 2: I Can Help You Update the Feed Once you have a new 3000x3000 image:
Upload it to Archive.org (or GitHub with your RSS feed) Get the new URL Tell me the new URL and I'll update your RSS feed with it
